title: Will AI Cite Your Brand?
description: GEO is reshaping digital discovery and changing how users search online.
content:
Large language models (LLMs) like ChatGPT, Gemini, Perplexity, and Claude now function as answer engines. Rather than listing links, they synthesize information and produce conversational responses to users’ queries, sometimes with citations. Your brand’s visibility no longer depends on your Google ranking, but rather on whether AI references your expertise when generating answers. What AI algorithms prefer, and why traditional SEO isn’t enough SEO still matters and remains highly relevant. Ranking well in search engine results, optimizing metadata, and creating authoritative, keyword-rich content are foundational practices that continue to support discoverability. But LLMs go beyond traditional ranking signals, and that’s where generative engine optimization (GEO) and answer engine optimization (AEO) come in.

These frameworks extend classic SEO principles into the realm of generative AI and are already reshaping how people discover brands and make purchasing decisions.
• Answer engine optimization focuses on structuring content in a way that helps AI engines extract direct and summarized answers, typically displayed in SERPs as featured snippets, answer boxes, or other instant answer formats. AEO strategies are becoming increasingly relevant as search experiences evolve to include AI-powered features, such as Google AI Overviews, Bing Copilot, and Perplexity AI.
• Generative engine optimization, on the other hand, is about influencing how LLMs generate answers, with emphasis on semantics, structure, and context. It’s about being present in the knowledge base that tools like ChatGPT, Gemini, and Claude use to answer queries, even when your site isn’t directly linked or cited. In practical terms, both approaches involve making your insights and brand part of the broader content ecosystem, especially through credible media coverage and well-structured, high-quality content. Why it matters: The data behind the shift

A Muck Rack study released in July analyzed over one million user prompts and found that 96 percent of links cited by AI fall within the communications scope—such as stories from journalistic entities, owned and external blogs, NGO websites, and academic sources. High‑authority outlets like Reuters, AP News, Yahoo Finance, and TIME account for a large share of these citations. What’s more, LLM traffic has quadrupled—from under 1.3 percent in January 2024 to 5.6 percent of U.S. desktop search traffic by June 2025. Meanwhile, Bain & Company reports that 80 percent of consumers now rely on zero‑click results for at least 40 percent of their searches, cutting organic web traffic by an estimated 15–25 percent. These figures reflect a clear behavioral shift: Users are resolving queries directly through AI-generated answers, without ever clicking through to a traditional website.

Here are five actionable strategies to help your brand become more visible in AI-generated search results: 1. Answer real user questions clearly: Use conversational language and structure content around actual queries your audience is likely to ask.

2. Build a strong media presence: Appear in third-party content that AI tools already value and trust. Media mentions, interviews, expert commentary, and thought leadership all count. 3. Diversify across AI models: According to the Muck Rack study: 4. Structure your content for both humans and machines: AI prefers content that’s easy to digest: clear headings, FAQs, bullet points, and short paragraphs all help machines parse information effectively.



5. Blend GEO/AEO with SEO: Technical SEO ensures your content is discoverable and crawlable, but storytelling, credibility, and authority drive AI inclusion. Our strategy in action: Media mentions via listicles and roundups Over the past year, my team began adapting our content strategy for GEO and AEO. One of the most effective tactics has been publishing high-quality listicles and expert roundups across trusted, industry-relevant outlets. These pieces position our company as a solution for services such as content marketing, online visibility, digital PR, and entrepreneur toolkits.

By consistently showing up in well-structured, high-authority content, we’ve seen a clear uptick in AI-generated answers mentioning our services. Today, our brand appears in responses to queries like “best platforms for guest posting” or “sponsored content platforms.” In some cases, ChatGPT and Google AI Overviews even include links to media that mention us. That visibility is not coincidental. It’s the result of a deliberate content strategy rooted in GEO and AEO: publishing content where AI can find it, structuring it for machine readability, and building trust through credible media exposure. The future of discoverability belongs to communicators

GEO and AEO aren’t just new acronyms, they are a wake-up call for how modern discoverability works. And for PR, content, and marketing teams, it presents a massive opportunity. Generative and answer searches favor the very things communications teams do best: clarity, authority, and relevance. It values well-structured, trustworthy information. GEO and AEO blend the strategic rigor of SEO with the narrative strength of PR. This is the time for integrated communications teams—PR, marketing, and content—to collaborate more closely than ever. Because today, when someone asks a question in a tool like ChatGPT or Gemini, the answer isn’t coming from who ranks highest. It’s coming from who’s most frequently and credibly mentioned. You’re no longer competing for position. You’re competing for inclusion.
summary: The article discusses the shift in AI-generated search results from large language models (LLMs) like ChatGPT, Gemini, Perplexity, and Claude, which synthesize information and respond to users’ queries with conversational responses. These models are replacing traditional search engine ranking signals with the importance of AI referencing your expertise in generating answers. The author suggests that while traditional SEO is still relevant, AI algorithms prefer to use keywords in their answers, these shifts shift focus on presenting brands with authoritative, keyword-rich content. The article also notes a shift in how users resolve queries directly through AI rather than directly through traditional websites. The study by Muck Rack found that 96 percent of links cited by AI fall within the communications scope, with high-authority outlets such as Reuters, AP News, Yahoo Finance, and TIME accounting for a large share of these citations. Meanwhile, Bain & Company reports that 80 percent of consumers now rely on zero‑click results for at least 40 percent of their searches, cutting organic web traffic by an estimated 15–25 percent. The authors suggest actionable strategies to help your brand become more visible in these results.
shortSummary: The future of AI-powered search engines like LLMs are shifting focus to creating authoritative, context-rich content that enhances brand visibility and credibility through media coverage and media.

scraped_sources.text:
Brief
At a Glance
- Marketing executives tailor their customer strategies around search engine results, but search is changing quickly.
- AI search engines and AI summaries on results pages are taking a bite out of clickthrough traffic.
- Bain’s research finds that 80% of consumers rely on these “zero-click” results at least 40% of the time.
- Brands will need to rethink their marketing strategies to avoid falling behind in this new era of search.
For years, marketers have worked to master search algorithms and position their companies well in search results and generate sales. Some invested in rich content and thoughtful optimizations, while others chased quick fixes like keyword stuffing.
Now, the rise of AI search engines and generative summaries has upended traditional search behavior, delivering answers directly on results pages and removing the need for users to click through to another site. Bain’s recent survey finds that about 80% of consumers now rely on “zero-click” results in at least 40% of their searches, reducing organic web traffic by an estimated 15% to 25% (see Figure 1). The speed of this upheaval leaves marketers with an urgent question: How do we engage consumers when clicks and site visits are disappearing?
A new era of search
Two tectonic shifts are disrupting search: generative AI summaries delivered by traditional search engines (for example, Google and Bing) and the rise of large language models (LLMs) for search (such as Perplexity and ChatGPT Search).
On traditional search engines, the zero-click trend is accelerating across demographics, with our research showing that about 60% of searches now end without the user progressing to another destination site. Even among those who say they are skeptical of generative AI, about half say that most of their queries are answered on the search page without a click.
In parallel, platforms like ChatGPT and Perplexity are surging in popularity. ChatGPT saw a 44% traffic boost in November 2024, and Perplexity reached 15 million monthly users in late 2024.
Customers indicate that LLMs are encroaching on traditional search engine use cases: roughly 40% to 70% of LLM users use the platforms to conduct research and summarize information (68%), understand the latest news and weather (48%), and ask for shopping recommendations (42%).
As organic clickthrough rates fall, marketers are losing share of voice in high-value, non-branded searches—that initial discovery phase where people seek answers and opinions before committing to a specific brand. These crucial moments are where customer discovery and subsequent conversion often occurs. Generative AI isn’t just disrupting search traffic—it’s turning the customer journey into an algorithm-driven narrative.
For Marketers, Generative AI Moves from Novelty to Necessity
Companies that scale up their initiatives will gain an edge by delivering consistent value and better engaging customers.
Preparing for a zero-click world
To succeed in this new consumer reality, search engine optimization will not be enough. Winning brands will accelerate and refine their SEO efforts, since these remain an important and effective means of reaching consumers. At the same time, brands should move quickly on two dimensions: pragmatic technical optimization strategies to set the foundation for LLM readability, and bold experiments to understand how to influence visibility and positioning for both search engine AI overviews and LLM engines. Actions that marketers can take to set the foundation for successful experimentation include:
- Optimize for AI crawlability. Adapt your content for semantic search, emphasizing high-intent, long-tail terms. Forget PDFs and gated content—they’re relics in an AI-driven ecosystem.
- Diversify content formats. Go beyond text. Use video and interactive formats to boost visibility in generative AI search. Prioritize deep topical authority over shallow keyword tactics.
- Redefine metrics. Shift from click-focused metrics to measuring search impressions and AI reach. Optimize for influence over direct conversions.
As zero-click searches and AI-driven engines redefine how people discover, learn, and decide, successful brands will embrace innovation and experiment boldly. Marketers should be rethinking search strategies in ways that will help maintain brand relevance and customer relationships in this new world of search.
About the Research
Data powered by Dynata, a leading global first-party data and insights platform.

Are your marketing efforts working together—or working against each other?
When brands send mixed messages across different channels, customers notice. Confusion creeps in, trust erodes, and campaigns lose their impact.
That’s where integrated marketing communication (IMC) comes in. It’s not just a buzzword – it’s a smarter way to manage your messaging.
IMC brings everything into sync.
From social posts to ad campaigns to email flows, it helps your brand sound and look consistent – no matter where customers encounter it.
This article breaks down what IMC is, why it matters, and how to get it right. You’ll get practical strategies, common pitfalls, and a clear plan to help your team stay aligned and get better results.
Key Takeaways
- IMC keeps your brand messaging consistent across every channel your audience sees.
- It improves brand recognition, builds trust, and drives engagement by aligning your marketing team and efforts.
- A strong IMC strategy starts with clear goals, defined audiences, and the right mix of channels.
- Success depends on cross-team coordination, real-time data tracking, and a feedback loop for ongoing improvement.
- IMC leads to stronger customer relationships and better campaign performance without wasting budget.
What is Integrated Marketing Communication?
Integrated marketing communications (IMC) is a strategic approach that combines all forms of marketing communication to deliver a consistent message to a target audience. By integrating marketing communications, businesses ensure that their marketing efforts are unified across multiple channels, creating a cohesive brand identity.
This approach is necessary in a marketing environment where consumers engage with brands across multiple channels and expect a consistent, seamless experience.
IMC involves coordinating marketing communications such as advertising, public relations, direct marketing, and social media marketing. The goal is to provide a unified and consistent experience for customers, enhancing brand loyalty and driving higher customer engagement.
An effective integrated marketing communication strategy helps businesses stand out by delivering consistent messages that resonate with consumers.
Components of Integrated Marketing Communications
An integrated marketing communications strategy encompasses several key components that work together:
1. Advertising
Advertising utilizes traditional advertising methods like television, radio, print media, and digital advertising to reach a broad audience. Through mass media, businesses can build brand awareness and communicate their brand message effectively.
2. Public Relations
Public relations activities manage the brand image and reputation by engaging with media channels, influencers, and the public. By leveraging public relations, businesses can shape public perception and build trust with their target audience.
3. Sales Promotion
Implementing promotional tools such as discounts, coupons, contests, and giveaways stimulates immediate sales and customer acquisition. Sales promotions attract new customers and encourage repeat purchases.
4. Direct Marketing
Direct marketing involves communicating directly with target customers through channels like email, mail, and SMS. Personalized communications enhance customer engagement and drive conversions.
5. Digital Marketing
Digital marketing leverages digital marketing channels such as websites, search engines, and email marketing. Advertising on platforms like Google and Facebook enables businesses to reach consumers online effectively.
6. Social Media Marketing
Utilizing social media channels like Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and LinkedIn allows businesses to engage with their target audience. Regular social media posts and interactions build a community around the brand.
7. Content Marketing
Creating valuable content such as blog posts, videos, podcasts, and infographics attracts and engages the target audience. Content marketing establishes the brand as an authority in its industry.
8. Personal Selling
A dedicated sales team interacts directly with customers, providing personalized solutions and building strong customer relationships. Personal selling is effective in complex sales situations where customer education is needed.
9. Event Marketing
Hosting or participating in events like trade shows, webinars, and conferences allows businesses to engage with customers and showcase their offerings. Events provide opportunities for face-to-face interactions.
10. Market Research
Conducting market research helps understand consumer behavior, preferences, and the customer decision-making process. Insights from consumer research inform marketing strategies and messaging.
Why is Integrated Marketing Communications Important?
Integrated marketing communications is important for several reasons:
- Consistent Messaging Across Multiple Channels: Delivering the same messaging across different marketing channels ensures that the brand message is reinforced at every touchpoint. Over 90% of consumers expect consistent interactions across different marketing channels. Consistent messages reduce confusion and build trust with the target audience.
- Enhanced Brand Identity: A consistent brand message strengthens brand identity, making it more recognizable and memorable. Companies with consistent branding across all platforms can increase revenue by up to 23%. This helps differentiate the brand from competitors.
- Efficient Use of Marketing Budgets: By coordinating marketing initiatives, businesses avoid duplication of efforts and ensure resources are allocated effectively. An integrated marketing campaign maximizes the impact of marketing budgets.
- Improved Customer Relationships: Providing a unified and consistent experience enhances customer satisfaction. Personalized communications and consistent messaging lead to increased brand loyalty. Nearly 89% of customers feel frustrated when they have to repeat their issues to multiple representatives.
- Brands that deliver a poor omnichannel customer experience retain only about one-third of their customers. This frustration can be minimized through integrated marketing communication, which ensures that all customer interactions are seamless and well-coordinated.
- Adaptability to Consumer Behavior: As consumer behavior changes, an integrated marketing communications plan allows businesses to adjust their strategies quickly. Monitoring customer data across various channels keeps companies ahead of trends.
- Higher Customer Engagement: Integrated marketing efforts drive higher customer engagement by delivering relevant and timely messages through preferred communication channels. Integrated marketing campaigns that use four or more digital channels outperform single or dual-channel campaigns by 300%. This multi-channel approach ensures that messages reach customers where they are most active, enhancing overall engagement and effectiveness.
- Competitive Advantage: Businesses that effectively implement integrated marketing communication programs gain a strategic advantage. Successful integrated marketing campaigns can lead to increased market share.
Developing an Integrated Marketing Communications Strategy
Creating a comprehensive marketing strategy involves several steps:
1. Identify the Target Audience
Use market research to understand the demographics, psychographics, and behaviors of the target customers. Knowing the target audience is critical for crafting effective marketing messages. Segmenting the audience helps tailor marketing strategies to specific groups for better results.
2. Set Clear Objectives
Define what the marketing efforts aim to achieve. Objectives could include increasing brand awareness, boosting sales, improving customer loyalty, or expanding into new markets. Clear objectives provide direction and a basis for measuring success.
3. Craft a Consistent Brand Message
Develop brand messaging that aligns with the company’s values and resonates with the target audience. This message should be consistent across all communication channels. Consistent messaging reinforces brand identity and makes it more memorable to consumers.
4. Select Appropriate Marketing Channels
Choose marketing channels that are most effective in reaching the target audience. This may include traditional channels like print and broadcast media, as well as digital marketing channels like social media and email. Using multiple channels ensures broader reach and maximizes marketing efforts.
5. Coordinate Marketing Initiatives
Ensure that all marketing campaigns and efforts are aligned. The marketing team, sales team, and brand managers should collaborate to deliver the same messaging. Regular communication between teams prevents inconsistencies and enhances efficiency.
6. Implement Integrated Marketing Campaigns
Launch campaigns that utilize multiple channels and communication tools simultaneously. Integrated marketing campaigns amplify the brand message and reach a wider audience. Coordinated campaigns create a unified and consistent experience for customers.
7. Personalize Communications
Use customer data to create personalized communications. Tailoring messages to individual preferences increases relevance and engagement. Personalization can lead to higher customer engagement and improved customer relationships.
8. Leverage Social Media Channels
Engage with customers on social media platforms. Social media marketing allows for two-way communication and builds community around the brand. Active social media presence helps in understanding consumer behavior and preferences.
9. Monitor and Measure Performance
Use analytics tools to track the performance of marketing campaigns. Key metrics might include customer engagement, conversion rates, and customer acquisition costs. Regular monitoring helps identify what’s working and what needs improvement.
10. Adjust Strategies Based on Data
Use insights from customer data and consumer research to refine marketing strategies. Continuous improvement ensures that marketing efforts remain effective. Being adaptable allows the marketing team to respond to market changes swiftly.
How to Measure and Evaluate the Effectiveness of Integrated Marketing Communications
Evaluating the success of integrated marketing communications programs is key for continuous improvement:
Establish Key Performance Indicators (KPIs)
Define measurable goals such as increased website traffic, higher sales, improved customer engagement, or enhanced brand loyalty. KPIs provide a clear benchmark to assess the success of marketing initiatives. They also help in aligning the marketing team’s focus toward common objectives.
Collect and Analyze Customer Data
Use CRM systems, web analytics, and social media analytics to gather data on customer interactions and behaviors. Analyzing this data reveals insights into consumer behavior and preferences. These insights can uncover new opportunities for targeted marketing efforts.
Evaluate Marketing Channels
Assess the performance of different marketing channels. Determine which channels drive the most engagement and conversions. Focusing on effective channels optimizes marketing budgets and efforts. Eliminating underperforming channels can improve overall campaign ROI.
Monitor Customer Engagement
Track how customers interact with marketing messages. Metrics like click-through rates, time spent on site, and social media interactions indicate engagement levels. High engagement often correlates with increased customer loyalty and conversions. Understanding engagement patterns helps tailor content to better meet customer interests.
Conduct Consumer Research
Gather direct feedback from customers through surveys, focus groups, and interviews. Understanding customer perceptions helps refine marketing messages. Consumer research can uncover unmet needs and opportunities for new marketing strategies. Engaging customers in research fosters a sense of involvement and can enhance brand loyalty.
Calculate Return on Investment (ROI)
Analyze the financial returns from marketing efforts relative to the costs. This helps optimize marketing budgets and allocate resources effectively. Positive ROI indicates that the marketing strategies are contributing to business growth. Regular ROI analysis ensures that marketing efforts are financially sustainable.
Adjust Marketing Strategies
Based on the evaluation, make necessary adjustments to the marketing strategies. This could involve reallocating resources to more effective channels or changing messaging. Continuous adaptation keeps the marketing efforts aligned with business goals. Proactive adjustments prevent wasted resources and improve campaign effectiveness.
Benchmark Against Competitors
Compare performance metrics with industry benchmarks and competitors. This provides context and helps identify areas for improvement. Understanding competitors’ strategies can inform your own strategic approach. Staying informed about industry trends helps maintain a competitive edge.
Implement Continuous Improvement
Use the insights gained to continuously refine and enhance the integrated marketing communications programs. Embracing continuous improvement leads to long-term success and sustainability. A culture of continuous improvement encourages innovation within the marketing team.
FAQs
How does Integrated Marketing Communication differ from traditional marketing strategies?
Integrated Marketing Communication focuses on delivering a consistent brand message across multiple channels, whereas traditional marketing strategies often operate in silos without coordination. IMC ensures all marketing efforts are aligned, enhancing brand identity and customer engagement.
What challenges might businesses face when implementing an Integrated Marketing Communications strategy?
Challenges include coordinating across different departments, ensuring consistent messaging, integrating various marketing channels, and analyzing customer data effectively. Overcoming these obstacles requires careful planning and collaboration within the marketing team.
How can technology enhance Integrated Marketing Communication efforts?
Technology enables better customer data collection, personalized communications, and efficient use of digital marketing channels. Tools like marketing automation, analytics software, and customer relationship management (CRM) systems help streamline marketing operations and improve targeting.
Is Integrated Marketing Communication suitable for small businesses?
Yes, small businesses can benefit from an integrated marketing approach by maximizing limited resources and delivering consistent messaging. By focusing on the most effective marketing channels for their target audience, small businesses can enhance brand identity and customer relationships.
How do cultural differences impact Integrated Marketing Communication in global markets?
Cultural differences affect how marketing messages are received in different regions. An effective integrated marketing communications plan should consider local customs, language nuances, and consumer behavior to ensure that the messaging resonates with the target audience in each market.
How Camphouse Supports Integrated Marketing Communication
Effective Integrated Marketing Communication (IMC) requires seamless coordination across multiple marketing channels. Camphouse simplifies this process by providing a centralized platform to manage campaigns, track performance, and ensure consistent messaging. It helps businesses align their marketing efforts, making it easier to create cohesive campaigns that reinforce brand identity.
With Camphouse, marketing teams can efficiently allocate resources, collaborate in real time, and monitor key metrics to optimize their strategies. The platform also offers tools to maintain brand consistency across digital and traditional channels.
Want to see how it works? Take a tour of Camphouse to discover how it can enhance your IMC strategy and improve marketing results.

National Recognition
Earn distinction from Inc. as one of America’s Best in Business and automatically be considered for Inc.’s prestigious Company of the Year award!
double-click to edit, do not edit in source
The Inc. Best in Business awards celebrate the projects and initiatives that were true business wins for your company over the past year. Whether it is about a new innovation, a standout marketing campaign, a creative use of AI, or a bold move that paid off, we want to hear your story.
Tell us about a successful project or business win and find your company among the winners that will be featured on Inc.com and in the pages of Inc. magazine. Hundreds of companies will be named to the Best in Business list, with even more recognized in several standout categories.
Now’s your chance to earn national—and global—recognition for the success you’ve had. Submit your project today and let the world see what makes your company the best in business.
For over 40 years, Inc. magazine has been devoted to recognizing America’s most dynamic businesses and honoring the great things they do. This year, hundreds of companies will make the cut and be honored in print and online. Honorees in 2025 will enjoy the following benefits:
Earn distinction from Inc. as one of America’s Best in Business and automatically be considered for Inc.’s prestigious Company of the Year award!
Be featured in the Winter issue of Inc. magazine, get a dedicated company profile on Inc.com, and receive national and local media coverage.
Every application will be seen and evaluated directly by Inc.’s editors, who will source stories and articles directly from the honorees and applicant pool.
Show your current employees that all of their long days and nights of hard work are paying off, and improve recruiting opportunities with prospective employees.
Applying is simple! Fill out the online application, where you will enter a few details about your company and answer three questions about your company’s achievement:
Describe a specific project, initiative, or innovation your organization achieved over the past year that is noteworthy.
Explain how the outcome of this project is a win for your company, leadership team, or industry, and how it sets you apart from your competitors.
Cite some metrics over the past 12 months, directly related to this project, that show positive business outcomes resulting in a win.
You will then select which business categories you’d like to apply for—the more categories you apply to, the higher the chances of being recognized. You can see a list of award categories below. That’s it!
Apply Now
Preferred-Rate Deadline: August 15
All applicants must first apply to the prestigious Best in Business main list—celebrating hundreds of companies for standout projects and initiatives over the past 12 months. Then, boost your chances for recognition by adding any of our exclusive award categories, with multiple winners honored in each.
Celebrating AI projects and initiatives that have delivered tangible results—whether through increased efficiency, cost savings, improved customer experiences, or new revenue opportunities— by demonstrating clear, measurable wins for the organization.
Celebrating successful projects or initiatives built without external funding—highlighting the creativity, resilience, and resourcefulness of founders and teams.
Recognizing the branding, guerrilla marketing, pop-up, experiential, and social media campaigns of upstart companies that have successfully challenged industry leaders and won devoted communities of customers.
Recognizing successful projects or initiatives that resulted from the partnership of two or more companies.
Honoring projects or initiatives that have successfully built new communities or deepened engagement within existing ones—fostering connection, participation, and lasting value for their members.
Recognizing outstanding projects or initiatives from family-owned businesses.
Recognizing projects or initiatives that successfully attracted investment or were a direct result of investment.
Recognizing groundbreaking innovations, inventions, or products of all types that have delivered meaningful outcomes, marking them as true wins worth celebrating.
Celebrating bold brand marketing and other strategies and campaigns that truly moved the needle. Advertising, brand marketing, digital marketing, and performance marketing will be recognized in this category.
Celebrating projects or initiatives that have made a measurable, positive impact on society, whether by addressing social challenges, advancing equity, improving well-being, or fostering sustainable change in communities.
Honoring social media campaigns or innovations that have driven significant results, such as increased engagement, brand awareness, audience growth, or business impact.
Get recognized as one of the top companies in your region, whether you’re leading in the Mid-Atlantic, Midwest, Northeast, Pacific, Rocky Mountain, Southeast, or Southwest.
Whether you’re a scrappy startup or a powerhouse enterprise, get recognized for achieving excellence at your scale: Small and Mighty (0-49 employees), Medium (50-99 employees), Large (100-499 employees), Extra Large (500+ employees).
Whether you’re building momentum or leading your market, get recognized for what you’ve accomplished at your revenue level: Lean and Mean (under $5 million in gross revenue), Prosperous and Thriving ($5 million to $50 million in gross revenue), Robust and Powerful ($50 million and up in gross revenue).
From rising stars to legacy leaders, showcase how your company is making its mark at every stage of growth: On the Rise (0-4 years in business), Established Excellence Companies (5-14 years in business), Legacy Companies (15+ years in business).
Honoring outstanding leaders who have successfully guided a key project or initiative, delivering significant results for their organization through strategic vision, effective execution, and impactful leadership.
The early-rate deadline is Friday, July 18, at 11:59 p.m. PT.
The preferred-rate deadline is Friday, August 15, at 11:59 p.m. PT.
The final deadline to apply is Friday, September 12, at 11:59 p.m. PT.
All applicants will be notified via email if they were chosen for the list.
We’ll send you a complimentary honoree toolkit to help you promote this incredible honor.
All Inc. Best in Business honorees will appear in the Winter issue of Inc. magazine and on Inc.com
Preferred-Rate Deadline: August 15
The Inc. Best in Business awards are open to all companies—public, private, nonprofit, U.S.-based, and international. Applicants must apply to the Main List to showcase standout work across industries, and may apply to optional additional categories for more visibility.
Inc. editors will review all entries. Honorees will be announced on Inc.com in December 2025 and in the Winter 2025/2026 issue of Inc. magazine. Applicants will be notified by mid-November 2025 whether they have made the list.
See your win immortalized in pages of the Winter issue of Inc. magazine, get a dedicated company profile on Inc.com, and receive national and local media coverage.
2024 List

argos_summary: Large language models (LLMs) like ChatGPT and Gemini are transforming search behavior by providing direct answers to user queries, diminishing the importance of traditional SEO. As a result, brands must adopt generative engine optimization (GEO) and answer engine optimization (AEO) strategies to enhance their visibility in AI-generated search results. These strategies emphasize the need for clear, structured content and a strong media presence to ensure inclusion in AI responses, as consumer reliance on zero-click results continues to rise.
